title-group.article-title: Nonconvergence/Improper Solution Problems With the Correlated-Trait Correlated-Method Parameterization of a Multitrait–Multimethod Matrix

author-notes.corresp: Levent Dumenci, Virginia Commonwealth University, PO Box 980149, Richmond, VA 23298-0149, USA Email: ldumenci@vcu.edu

abstract.p: Estimation problems associated with the correlated-trait correlated-method (CTCM) parameterization of a multitrait–multimethod (MTMM) matrix are widely documented: the model often fails to converge; even when convergence is achieved, one or more of the parameter estimates are outside the admissible parameter space. In this study, the authors explore the potential contributions of two factors to the occurrence of nonconvergence and inadmissible solutions: (a) the minimum number of indicators per factor and (b) the deviation of the MTMM matrix from the CTCM model beyond sampling variability. Analyses of two published occupational preference data sets involving six traits and five methods and a simulation study show that the probability of obtaining problematic solutions diminishes as the minimum number of indicators per factor increases. Also, isolating factors contributing to model misfit beyond sampling variability reduces the probability of obtaining problematic solutions by one half. The implications of these findings for choosing a measurement design that improves the probability of achieving a proper solution in the analysis of an MTMM matrix using the CTCM parameterization are discussed.

body.p: Multitrait–multimethod (MTMM) measurement design plays a pivotal role in establishing the convergent and discriminant validity of educational and psychological measures (Campbell & Fiske, 1959). The standard MTMM design commonly refers to a fully crossed measurement of I traits and J methods (I × J). There are several models and procedures for analyzing the MTMM matrix. Dumenci (2000) provides the structural equation modeling parameterizations of commonly used MTMM models. In an edited volume, Eid and Diener (2006) present novel examples of MTMM models in applied settings.

Within the confirmatory factor analytic framework, the correlated-trait correlated-method (CTCM) parameterization is one of the earliest model-based approaches to analyzing MTMM data (Joreskog, 1971; Widaman, 1985). This parameterization provides a viable alternative to the Campbell and Fiske (1959) method of eyeballing and averaging the correlations. Over time, a major caveat of the CTCM has been noted and widely documented: The model suffers from identifiability and estimation problems (Bagozzi, 1993; Becker & Cote, 1994; Brannick & Spector, 1990; Convey, 1996; Kenny & Kashy, 1992; Kumar & Dillon, 1992; Marsh, 1989; Marsh & Bailey, 1991; Marsh & Grayson, 1995; Saris, 1990; Wothke, 1996). Specifically, the model fit function either fails to converge or an improper convergence yields inadmissible parameter estimates (i.e., obtained estimates are outside the boundaries of the admissible parameter space, e.g., factor correlations greater than the absolute value of unity or negative variances). When these problems occur they prevent applied researchers from making inferences regarding convergent and discriminant validity. While acknowledging these limitations, however, Lance, Noble, and Scullen (2002) argue in favor of the CTCM model on both theoretical and substantive grounds provided that an admissible solution is obtained. Improving our understanding of which factors result in improper solutions will allow applied researchers to make more informed decisions about selecting the CTCM model for MTMM matrices.

The purpose of this study is to test the effects of (a) the minimum number of indicators per factor and (b) model misfit beyond sampling variability on the probability of obtaining a nonconvergent/inadmissible solution from the CTCM analysis of MTMM data. In the sections that follow, we briefly introduce the CTCM model, discuss the possible role that both the size of the MTMM matrix and the presence of additional model misfit factors contribute to the likelihood of a nonconvergent/inadmissible solution, and describe the results from the analyses of two published MTMM matrices and a simulation study to test the study hypotheses.

sec.title: CTCM Model for MTMM Data
sec.p: The CTCM can be expressed as

where yij refers to the observed variable for the ith trait (i = 1, . . ., I) measured by the jth method (j = 1, . . ., J), Ti and Mj refer to the latent variables representing the ith trait and jth method, respectively, with corresponding factor loadings of λTij and λMij, and rij refers to the uniqueness representing all factors contributing to the observed variable not accounted for by the trait and method factors in the model. The model supports a freely estimated covariance structure between trait factors and between method factors, but the model assumes that the trait factors are orthogonal to the method factors and that both sets of factors are uncorrelated with the unique variables. The model estimates I + J factors from I × J trait-method units (observed variables). Under the assumption that the rijs are uncorrelated, the variance of the observed variable, Var(yij), can be additively partitioned into trait [(λTij)2 × Var(Ti)], method [(λMij)2 × Var(Mj)], and residual [Var(rij)] components.

sec.title: Nonconvergent/Improper CTCM Solutions
sec.p: In addition to small sample sizes and the listwise-deletion method for handling missing data, Marsh (1989) alluded to the possibility that a small number of indicators per factor and model misspecification could be contributing to problematic solutions in CTCM models. Brannick and Spector (1990) fit the CTCM model to 18 previously published MTMM matrices, 16 of which had a minimum of three indicators per factor and the remaining two a minimum of four indicators per factor. None of the 16 CTCM models yielded an admissible solution. For the two remaining CTCM models with a minimum of four indicators per factor, one provided an admissible solution but the other did not. Similarly, Becker and Cote (1994) analyzed 17 previously published MTMM matrices using the CTCM model, 15 of which had a minimum of three indicators per factor and two with a minimum of four indicators per factor. They reported problematic solutions for all matrices, with the exception of two matrices: one with a 3-trait × 3-method and the other with a 7-trait × 4-method. Collectively, results from the reanalysis of these published MTMM matrices suggested that improper CTCM solutions may be less of a problem for large MTMM matrices.

Marsh (1989), in his use of the term model misspecification, referred to the possibility that the CTCM may not be the model that generates the MTMM matrix. Consequently, the presence of model misspecification would likely result in nonconvergent/inadmissible solutions for CTCM models. A nonsignificant p value associated with a chi-square test of model fit would provide statistical evidence that the difference between the observed MTMM matrix and the MTMM matrix implied by the CTCM model could be due to sampling variability. The p value associated with the chi-square test of model fit can be meaningfully interpreted only when the model properly converges. Hence, there is an inherent difficulty in attributing the problem of nonconvergent/inadmissible solutions to model misspecification in the applied setting because the “correct model” is unknown to the researcher. To overcome this difficulty, we employ a simulation study to isolate those factors contributing to model misfit beyond sampling variability and to determine if these factors lead to nonconvergent/inadmissible solutions in the CTCM model.

sec.title: Method
sec.p: We fit a CTCM model to two 6-trait × 5-method MTMM matrices originating from the Self-Directed Search (SDS; Holland, 1985a), an instrument designed to operationalize Holland’s theory of vocational interests (Holland, 1985b): one published by Dumenci (1996) using a U.S. college student sample (N = 700) and the other by Yang, Lance, and Hui (2006) from an adult mainland China/Hong Kong sample (N = 801). The SDS is designed to measure six traits (Realistic, Investigative, Artistic, Social, Enterprising, and Conventional) by five methods (Activities, Competencies, Occupations, and self-reported Abilities and Skills). In addition to the two observed MTMM matrices, we simulated data from the model-implied MTMM matrices. Each simulation sample size was set equal to its corresponding published study. The purpose of analyzing simulated data was to isolate factors contributing to model misfit beyond sampling variability in our assessment of nonconvergence/improper solutions for the CTCM model.

We fit the CTCM model to all possible trait–method combinations ranging from a 3-trait × 3-method to 6-trait × 5-method MTMM matrix. Each MTMM matrix was obtained by eliminating various row(s) and column(s) of the 6-trait × 5-method MTMM matrices. The CTCM model was fit to 2,688 MTMM matrices: 800 MTMM matrices with 3-trait × 3-method = (200 possible 3-trait × 3-method combinations from the 6-trait × 5-method MTMM matrices) × (2 observed MTMM matrices) × (2 model-implied MTMM matrices), 600 MTMM matrices with 4-trait × 3-method, and so on, and concluding with the four 6-trait × 5-method MTMM matrices. The outcome variable, denoted as Problem, was binary and took a value of zero when the estimated model properly converged and the parameter estimates were within the allowable parameter space or one otherwise.

sec.title: Results
sec.p:
The 6-trait × 5-method CTCM models for both the U.S. and Chinese observed and simulated samples converged properly and yielded admissible solutions. The fit statistics were as follows:
χ
( 350 )
2
= 1453.72, p < .001; root mean square error of approximation (RMSEA) = .067; confirmatory fit index (CFI) = .886; Tucker–Lewis index (TLI) = .859; and
χ
( 350 )
2
= 1901.93, p < .001; RMSEA = .074; CFI = .884; TLI = .856, for the observed U.S. and Chinese data, respectively. Fit statistics for the corresponding simulated data were as follows:
χ
( 350 )
2
= 337.42, p = .676; RMSEA = .000; CFI = 1.000; TLI = 1.002, and
χ
( 350 )
2
= 331.21, p = .758; RMSEA = .000; CFI = 1.000; TLI = 1.002, for samples drawn from the U.S. and Chinese model-implied MTMM matrices, respectively. These fit statistics confirmed that factors beyond sampling variability were present, that they were likely to have contributed to the real data-model discrepancy (i.e., model misfit), and that these factors were absent in the simulated data.

Figure 1 depicts the proportion of problems versus the minimum number of indicator variables per factor in the MTMM matrix for both the observed and simulated data. The highest problem proportion of 80.50% (322/400) was obtained by fitting the observed 3-trait × 3-method matrices. The unweighted average problem proportion was 70.00% (range = 61.50% to 80.50%) for the real data with a minimum of three indicators per factor. This proportion decreased to 37.75% (range = 20.00% to 49.33%) when the minimum number of indicators per factor increased to four and further decreased to 4.17% (range = 0.00% to 8.33%) for five indicators per factor.

caption.p: Problem rate versus the minimum number of indicators per factor

sec.p: The proportion of problems for the simulated data showed a similar pattern. The average problem proportion for the three-, four-, and five-indicator conditions were 32.10% (range = 24.17% to 48.15%), 18.42% (range = 16.68% to 20.00%), and 4.17% (range = 0.00% to 8.33%), respectively. Overall, an increase in the minimum number of indicators per factor resulted in a linear decrease in the proportion of problems for both the real and simulated data. The average problem proportion for the simulated data was roughly half of the problem proportion observed for the real data.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The 3-trait × 3-method combination is the most commonly encountered measurement design adopted in MTMM studies. Applying the CTCM model to this type of study either did not converge or resulted in an inadmissible solution 80.50% of the time based on the real data examined here. One plausible explanation for such a high problem proportion is that the assumed model generation mechanism is incorrectly specified for the MTMM matrix. Factors contributing to model misfit beyond sampling variability explain a reduction in the proportion of problems from 80.50% to 48.25%. The fact that 48.25% is much greater than 0% suggests that an ill-specified CTCM model is only a partial explanation of the underlying phenomena. In applying the CTCM model to the 3-trait × 3-method MTMM matrix, the model estimates six factors from nine observed variables. Perhaps this is asking too much of the data. That is, the CTCM is an overparameterized model for the 3-trait × 3-method MTMM matrix.

When the minimum number of indicators per factor is less than five, the potential for problems remain high, that is, problem proportions range from 20.00% (6-trait × 4-method) to 80.50% (3-trait × 3-method). Increasing the minimum number of indicators per factor from three to four reduces the proportion of problems by one half. Similarly, isolating factors that contribute to model misfit beyond sampling variability also reduces the proportion of problems by as much as one half when the minimum number of indicators per factor is held constant. Applied researchers are well advised to not consider the CTCM model for their MTMM data when the minimum number of indicators per factor is three or less.

Some caution is warranted in interpreting the results from this study. After all, the 2,688 MTMM matrices analyzed here originated from two published MTMM matrices, both of which converged properly. Therefore, the proportion of admissible solutions may be optimistic (i.e., lower bound estimates) in this study. Ideally, all MTMM matrices should come from independent samples. A large number of MTMM matrices obtained from independent samples, especially those with a minimum of five or more indicators per factor, should be used to independently replicate the results of this study. A parametric model was not used here to relate the design variables to the binary outcome due to the dependency of the MTMM matrices used in this study.

To conclude, results from the analysis of real and simulated data suggest that the size of the MTMM matrix exerts a key role in fitting the CTCM model. As the minimum number of indicators per factor increases from three to five, a steep reduction in the observed problem proportion suggests that the prospect of convergence and estimation concerns should not be used to discredit the CTCM model for a sufficiently large MTMM matrix. Here, “sufficiently large” may be defined as a minimum of four or more indicators per factor or as the average number of indicators per factor achieves a set size, that is, (I × J)/(I + J) ≥ 2.5.

In the sense of Pedhazur and Schmelkin (1991), one can go one step further and conclude that nonconvergence and inadmissible solution issues often encountered with the CTCM model are not a statistical problem per se. Rather, it is the mismatch between the measurement design (e.g., the adoption of up to three indicators per factor) and the model choice (the CTCM parameterization of the MTMM matrix). Regardless of how we rephrase the issue, most MTMM studies that rely on a fully crossed 3-trait × 3-method design are highly unlikely to result in an admissible solution with the CTCM parameterization. This is a serious limitation in applied settings. It is not surprising that the developers of new methods for analyzing the MTMM matrix have consistently cited the prospect of estimation problems to justify yet another parameterization of the MTMM matrix over the past four decades. Perhaps this “motivational” aspect of the CTCM model will serve as its primary legacy for the future.

ack.p: Preliminary results from this study were presented at the International Meeting of Psychometric Society, Athens, Georgia (July, 2010).
